mu essomampimo, Obuwanvu okwebulungula enkula etali nnetoloovu(non-circular shape) buyitibwa obwebulungirivu(Perimeter).
Okwebulungula ekintu si kye kimu n’okukyetoloola. Okukyetoloola kitegeeza nti akatonnyeze kaakyo ak’amakkati(midpoint) okakozeeko enkula ennetoloovu=entoloovu(circle). Kyokka Okukyebulungula kitegeeza nti tokoze nkula netoloovu.
(v) Obwagaagavu(Area). Mu butuufu entoloovu luba lutoloovu=lukoloboze olwetoloovu, ekitegeeza nti nga enkoloboze(lines) endala zonna ,lunila empimo emu(one dimension) , ey’obuwanvu. N’olwekyo bwe twogera ku bwagaagavu bw’entoloovu tuba tutegeeza bwagaagavu bw’ekibangirizi ekiri munda mw’olutoloovu(olukoloboze olwetoloovu).
(vi) Ekisittale(Chord).Ekisittale (ekitundu ky’omusittale) kitegeeza ekikoloboze(ekitundu ky’olukoloboze olugolokofu) ekikwataganya obutonnyeze obubiri bwonna ku ntoloovu(enkula ennetoloovu).
(vii) Olikwata oba Olutuuliro(Tangent). Luno luba lukoloboze oluyita wabweru ku ntoloovu ne lujikoonako ku katonnyeze kamu kokka.
(viii) Olusalaganya (Secant). Luno luba lukoloboze olusala mu ntoloovu ku butonnyeze buburi bwokka.
(ix) Buli lw’ogabiza Olusekkati(Diameter) mu obwetoloovu(circumference) bw’entoloovu yonna oba ofuna entakyuka(constant). Entakyuka eno eyitibwa “Paayi”(Pi) era ekunuukiriza 3.142
(x) Entoloovu (=enkula ennetoloovu) kika kya eripuso(ellipse) . Singa oddira ebisiisi(acces) by’eripuso n’obifuula obuwanvu bwe bumu , ekivaamu eba nkula ennetoloovu.
(xi) Oyinza okusonjola entoloovu nga enkula etondekebwawo nga ekitendero(plane) kisaze mu nsoggo=enkula ey’olusoggo(cone) ku mpeto ennesimbu (at right angles) ku ekisiisi y’ensoggo(at the cone’s axis).

Obulwadde bw'Obutalaba biri wala:
Obutalaba biri wala y'embeera ekitangaala we kikubira kungulu ku liiso, n'ekirema kuyingira munda nga bwe kyandibadde.
Era kino kiviirako omuntu okutandika okuba nga tasobola kulaba biri wala kyokka ng'ebimuli okumpi abiraba bulungi. Mu bubonero obulala kuliko okulumwa omutwe, ssaako okukaluubirizibwa ng'otunula. Obulwadde buno singa busajjuka, omulwadde yandifa akatundu k'eriiso akakuŋŋaanya ekitangaala, okufuna obulwadde bw'ekiyira (cataract) ssaako obwa glaucama.
Ebireeta endwadde eno kirowoozebwa nti kuliko ensonga y'obuzaale wamu n'ebyo ebitwetoolodde, nga mwe muli omuntu okukola omulimu ogumwetaagisa okutunuulira ekintu nga kisemberedde nnyo amaaso, omuntu okumala ekiseera ekiwanvu ng'ali mu kizimbe munda, ssaako okuba nga mu booluganda lwe waliwo omu gwe bwali bukutte.
Okukebera endwadde eno, bakozesa kye bayita ekigezo ky'amaaso, okuzuula ob'asobola okulaba ebiri okumpi era n'ebiri ewala.
Waliwo omukisa gw'abaana abato okuwona endwadde eno ey'obutalaba biri wala, nga mwe muli okutandika okubeeranga wabweru w'enju era nga bafuna ekitangaala ky'obutonde. Oba obulwadde buno buyinza okuggyibwawo ng'omulwadde akozesa gaalubindi, oba okulongoosa amaaso ago.
Obulwadde buno bwe businga okukwata amaaso mu nsi yonna, nga bukwata abantu abawererako ddala, naye ng'omuwendo gw'abalwadde gugenze gweyongera okuva eyo mu myaka egy'ataano (1950), era bwe bumu ku nsibuko y'obuzibe bw'amaaso mu bantu.

Olunekkati (radius):
Olunakkati(Radius)) . 
Olunakkati kiva mu bigambo by’Oluganda “olukoloboze olusala mu “lusekkati” ebitundu bibiri”. Mu luganda amannya agatandika ne “n” galaga “kitundu” ate agatandika ne “s” galaga “kiramba”. 
Yadde nga omusajja yenkanankana n’omukyala ng’abantu, omukyala yatwalibwanga okuba ekitundu ky’omusajja. Mu ngeri ye’emu olunakkati=olukoloboze olw’amakkati g’olusekkati, lutwalibwa okuba ekitundu ky’olusekkati(Diamater).

Olusekkati (Diameter):
Olusekkati(Diameter)
Olusekkati (D)= Olukoloboze olusala mu makkati g’entoloovu. 
Olusekkati lukubisaamu “olunakkati” (Radius) emirundi ebiri.

Okuvaamu olubito:
Okuvaamu olubuto kwe kufa kw'omwana abeera akyali mu lubuto ng'akyakula era nga tannakula kutuuka kuzaalibwa. Obumu ku bu bubonera obutera okweyolekera mu kuvaamu kw'olubuto kuliko, okuvaamu ennyo omusaayi(nga guyita mu bitundu by'ekyama) era nga kino kitera okujjirako n'obulumi. Mu birala kuliko okuvaamu ebintu ebiringa ebitole by'omusaayi n'ebirala.
Ebimu ku biyinza okuleetawo okuvaamu kw'olubuto kuliko ebintu ng'abazadde bombi bakadde, oba ng'omu mukadde, era kyandireetebwa embuto endala eziba zaavaamu edda, okunywa sigala oba okusemberera abamunywa. Mu birala mulimu omugejjo, endwadde ya ssukaali, ssaako ebiragalalagala oba okukozesa ennyo omwenge n'ebiringa ebyo.
Buli mukazi lw'agenda ng'akula okuva ku mwaka ng'asatu(30) emikisa gye okuvaamu embuto nagyo gyeyongera. Embuto ezivaamu kinaana ku buli kikumi(80%) zisinga kuviramu ku bbanga lya wiiki kkumi na bbiri ezisooka, oluvannyuma lw'okufuna olubuto.

Obwetoloovu (Circumference):
Obwetoloovu(Circumference) okusinziira ku Charles Muwanga .
Obuwanvu okwetoloola enkula ennetoloovu=entoloovu(circle) ky’ekiyitibwa Obwetoloovu. Weetegereze nti 
mu essomampimo, obuwanvu(length) okwebulungula enkula etali nnetoloovu(non-circular shape) buyitibwa "obwebulungirivu"(Perimeter).
Okwebulungula ekintu si kye kimu n’okukyetoloola. Okukyetoloola kitegeeza nti akatonnyeze kaakyo ak’amakkati(midpoint) oketoloolodde mu ndabika ey'enkula ennetoloovu=entoloovu(circle). Kyokka Okukyebulungula kitegeeza nti tokoze ndabika ya nkula ennetoloovu.

Obwebulungirivu (Perimeter):
Obwebulungirivu(Perimeter) okusinziira ku Charles Muwanga !
Weetegereze nti mu essomampimo, Obuwanvu okwebulungula enkula etali nnetoloovu(non-circular shape) buyitibwa "obwebulungirivu"(Perimeter).
Okwebulungula ekintu si kye kimu n’okukyetoloola. 
Okukyetoloola kitegeeza nti akatonnyeze kaakyo ak’amakkati(midpoint) okakozeeko enkula ennetoloovu=entoloovu(circle). Kyokka Okukyebulungula kitegeeza nti tokoze nkula netoloovu. Obuwanvu okwetoloola enkula ennetoloovu=entoloovu(circle) ky’ekiyitibwa Obwetoloovu. Weetegereze ebigambululo bino:
(a) Amagye g'omukago getooloode ekibuga Kigali.This implies that it is surrounded in circular shape, it is encircled.
(b)Amagye g'omugako gebulungudde ekibuga KIgali. This means that it is surrounded but not necessarily in a circular shape.

Entakyuka eya Paayi (the Pi constant):
Entakyuka eya Paayi (the Pi constant)okusinziira ku Charles Muwanga.
Buli lw’ogabiza Olusekkati(Diameter) mu obwetoloovu(circumference) bw’entoloovu yonna oba ofuna entakyuka(constant).
Entakyuka eno eyitibwa “Paayi”(Pi) era ekunuukiriza 3.142

Okukomola Abasajja:
Okukumola abasajja kwe kusalako oluliba lw'omu maaso olubeera ku busajja. Mu kukomola, eddagala erisannyalaza ery'enjawulo litera okukozesebwa, nga kino kiyambako okukendeeza ku bulumi ng'omuntu akomolebwa. Waliwo eddagala erisannyalaza eritera okukozesebwa eryekinnansi erisiigibwa obusiigibwa ku busajja naye ng'ate waliwo n'ezzungu eriyisibwa mu kayiso okusobola okusannyalala.
Ensonga ezireetera okukomola abasajja.
Ebiseera ebisinga wabeerawo okukomolebwa kw'abaana abalenzi n'abasajja abalondemu olw'ensonga z'eddiini oba ebyobuwangwa byabwe.
Kyokka ate omulundi omulala omuntu ayinza okukomolebwa lwa nsonga ya bujjanjabi oba okukendeeza ku mikisa gy'okukwatibwa endwadde. Era oluusi okukomolebwa kukolebwa nga bwe bujjanjabi bwokka obusoboka, gamba nga mu mbeera ng'oluliba olwo olubeera mu maaso g'obusajja lutono nnyo, era nga terukyakkiriza busajja kweyongera kukula, era ng'awo luba lulina okusalwako obusajja bukule. Oba singa wabaawo okukuubagana wakati w'oluliba olwo n'omutwe gw'obusajja, ekitera okuleetawo n'okufuna amabwa, olwo era omuntu aba alina okukomolebwa olw'embeera eno.
N'ekirala okukomolebwa kubaawo okwetangira n'okukendeeza ku mikisa ky'okukwatibwa endwadde ezikwata ebitundu ebikungaanya n'okutambuza omusulo ezitera okuleetebwa obukyafu.
Okukomola mu nsi yonna.
Ebitongole by'ebyobulamu mu nsi yonna bikubiriza abasajja n'abaana abalenzi okwekomoza, naye nga si kya buwaze. Obujulizi bulaga nti okukomolebwa kw'abasajja kukendeeza ku mikisa gy'okukwatibwa kw'akawuka akaleeta endwdde ya Mukenenya (siriimu) naddala mu basajja abeegatta n'abakazi ababeera wansi w'eddungu Sahara mu Afirika, era ekitongole ekikulira ebyobulamu mu nsi yonna kikubiriza abasajja okwekomoza ng'emu ku nkola ey'okwetagiramu endwadde ya siriimu (kikendeeza ku mikisa gy'okukwatibwa siriimu). Era kiyamba n'okwetangira endwadde nga kookolo w'obusajja, wamu n'endwadde ezikwata nga ziyita mu musulo.
Kiteeberezebwa nti abasajja ebitundu kimu kyakusatu mu nsi yonna bakomole naye gn'abasinga obungi basangibwa mu nsi z'Abayisiraamu ne mu Israel. Mu nsi ezo okukomolebwa kukolebwa lwa nsonga za ddiini. Mu nsi z'e Bulaaya (Europe), Amerika ey'amaserengeta n'ebitundu ebirala nga Asia okukomolebwa kutono nnyo ddala.

Okumaanyuuka enviiri:
Okumanyuuka enviiri kitegeeza omuntu okugenda ng'akuunyuuka enviiri ku mutwe oba okuva mu bitundu by'omubiri ebirala, naye ng'okusingira ddala ku mutwe.
Okumaanyuuka oba okukuunyuuka kw'enviiri kuno tekutera kujja na obulumi oba okulekawo enkovu, newankubadde ng'abamu kitera okubaleetera okutaataagaanyizibwamu mu bwongo bwabwe.
Ekireetera okumaanyuuka kw'enviiri.
Mu bika by'obulwadde buno mulimu okukuunyuuka enviiri okw'abasajja, okw'abakazi, okumera ekiwalaata ssaako n'okuseenyuuka kw'enviiri. Ebiviirako abasajja okukuunyuuka enviiri kuliko ensonga ez'obuzaale ssaako obutaffaali obuba mu mubiri gw'omusajja. Kyokka yo mu bakazi ekiviirako ensonga eno tekyekakasika bulungi.
Ekireeta ekiwalaata.
Naye ekireetawo okumera ekiwalaata kisinga kwesigamizibwa ku ndya embi, nga n'eky'okuseenyuuka enviiri kisinga kuva ku kwerariikirira nnyo buli kiseera, ate era kitera nnyo n'okulabikira mu bakazi abali embuto.
Ebimu ku bireeta okukuunyuuka enviiri nga tafunye buvune bwonna kuliko: omuntu okuba ng'asikaasika nnyo enviiri ze, eddagala eritera okujjanjaba endwadde, okuba n'endwadde ya Mukenenya (Siriimu) ssaako endya embi, omuli n'obutaba na kirungo kya munnyo ("iron") kimala mu mubiri. Kyokka byo ebireeta okumaanyuuka kw'enviiri okujja n'obulumi era n'okulekawo enkovu kuliko: endwadde ezireetebwa obuwuka gamba ng'ebiguuna, okuteeka omuntu mu byuma bye bakebeza endwadde, gamba ng'ekifaananyi (x-ray) n'ebirala.
Okukebera endwadde eno kisinziira ku kifo w'eba ekutte. Naye mu biyinza okuwonya endwadde eno kuliko okumanyiiza omubiri embeera y'obudde mw'oli, okukozesa eddagala ery'enjawulo, ssaako okulongoosa omutwe gw'omulwadde n'assibwako enviiri endala.

Endwadde y’Obulangula:
Obulangula (Trachoma) ndwadde y'amaaso ereetebwa obuwuka obuyitibwa "Chlomydia trachomatis". Obulangula bufuula eriiso okuba nga likambira era nga lisala, ekireetawo obulumi era n'okulwala kw'ekitundu ekibikka ku liiso, sinakindi n'okuzibira ddala amaaso. Obuwuka obuleeta endwadde eno busobola okusaasaanyizibwa singa amaaso gakwataganako n'ebintu ebirina akakwate konna ku maaso oba ennyindo y'omulwadde.
Obulwadde buno businga kusaasaanira mu baana okusinga abakulu. N'ebirala ebisaasaanya obulwadde buno kuliko obujama(obucaafu) obw'amazzi ate n'obwa kaabuyonjo (ttooyi). Ekirala kwe kubeera mu bifo eby'olukale (abantu abangi ennyo).
Engeri mwe tuyinza okuyita okweziyiza Obulangula ze zino: okukozesa amazzi amayonjo ate n'okufuba okukendeeza ku muwendo gw'abo ababulina nga bajjanjabibwa. Kino kiyinza okukolebwa nga wateekeddwawo okujjanjaba kw'abalina obulwadde buno, omulundi gumu, oba okujjanjaba abantu bonna abasangibwa mu bitundu obulwadde buno gye bumanyiddwa ennyo.
Obujjanjabi bwa Trachoma kuliko eddagala erimiribwa obumiribwa mu kamwa eriyitibwa "Azythromycin" oba eritonnyezebwa ku maaso eriyitibwa "Tetracycline". Kyokka singa obulwadde buno buba bumaze okuleeta enkovu ku bususu obubikka eriiso, olwo amaaso ago gaba geetaaga okulongoosa, okusobola okutereeza obukoowekoowe ate n'okutangira amaaso okuziba.
Ebibalo biraga nti abantu obukadde kinaana (80M) balwadde balina Obulangula mu nsi yonna. Obulwadde buno businga kukwata baana ne kuddako abakazi, olw'okuba nti bo babeera nnyo n'abaana okusinga abasajja. Era obulwadde buno buviriiddeko abantu abawererako ddala, obukadde bubiri mu emitwalo abiri, okuziba amaaso

Okuggya:
Okuggya buba buvune ku lususu oba ekitundu ky'omubiri ekirala, ekireetebwa ebintu ng'okuggya omuliro, okukubibwa amasannyalaze, ebidagala ebya kkemiko (chemicals) n'ebirala ebiyinza okwokya omubiri.
Okuggya kuno kuleetebwa ebintu eby'enkula yonna okwo nga kwe kuli n'omuliro gwennyini, naye nga mu bakyala kusinga kwesigamizibwa ku muliro gwe bafumbisa. Ebirala ebiyinza okuleetawo okuggya kuliko ettamiiro, okukommonta (okunywa) ebintu nga ssigala, oba abantu okusalawo bo bennyini ne beeyokya mu ngeri ey'okwesaanyaawo.
Engeri z'okuggya omuliro.
Okuggya okw'ekika ekisooka, kusinga kukoma ku lususu, nga bimyufu era nga bisinga kuwonera mu nnaku nga ssatu. Okuggya okw'omulundi ogwokubiri, byo biba byeyongeddeko munda mu lususu era olususu lusituka ne luzimba ebimmonde ebirimu amazzi (blisters) era biba n'obulumi bungiko. Okuwona kw'ebiwundu bino kwanditwala wiiki nga munaana(8), era ng'oluvannyuma lw'okuwona watera okusigalawo enovu ekiwundu ky'omuiro we kibadde.
Okuggya okw'olundi ogwokusatu, kwekwo okw'obutaffaali bw'olususu lwonna awo mu kifo awaba wayidde, ebintu ng'ennyingo ne biggya n'oluusi n'okutuuka ku ggumba ekiwundu ekyo kitera kuba kimyufu nnyo oba nga kiddugavu.
Okujjanjaba omuliro.
Obujjanjabi bw'ebiwundu bino businziira ku bunene bw'ekiwundu, anti obuwundu bw'omuliro obutonotono butera kwetaagisa ddagala lya bulijjo erikikkakkanya obulumi. Naye byo ebinene ennyo biba bisaana obujjajabi obw'enjawulo obutera okutwala ekiseera ekiwanvuko, okusinziira ku ktundu ky'omubiri ekiba kiyidde.
Ebiwundu biri eby'omulundi ogwokubiri biba byetaagisa okunaaza ng'okozesa ssabbuuni n'amazzi era n'okubisiba ppulasita.
Engeri y'okujjanjabamu ebimmonde ebiba bizimbye ku lususu olw'okuggya si nnambulukufu bulungi, naye oweebwa amagezi bwe kaba katono, kaleke, ate bwe kiba kinene kitulise n'amazzi ogakenenulemu mpolampola. Naye byo ebiwundu ebinene ennyo(eby'omulundi ogwokusatu) bitera kwetaagisa okubijjanjaba nga bakozesa enkola z'ebyokulongoosa, gamba nga enkola eyookusala akafi k'ennyama ku mubiri ewalala ne baziba ewali ekiwundu kyomuliro ekyo, ekiyitibwa 'skin grafting'. Ate era ebiwundu bino ebinene bitera okuviiramu okukwatibwa kw'endwadde nga 'Tetanus', ery'omulwadde yandibadde agemesebwa mangu ddala nga yaakaggya.
Newankubadde omuntu bw'aggya ennyo kiyinza okumuviiramu okufa, naye eddagala erizze livumbulwa okuva eyo mu myaka egy'enkaaga lyongedde okuwonya abantu naddala abaana abato n'abavubuka. Era ebivaamu eri omuntu ayidde byesigamizibwa nnyo ku bunene bw'ebbwa era n'emyaka gy'omulwadde.

Obulwadde bw’Embwa obuluma abantu:
Obulwadde bw’embwa obuluma abantu (Rabies) buviirako endwadde y’ebizimba mu bwongo, mu bantu ne mu nsolo endala. Embwa bw'eba ndwadde ya bulwadde ate n'eruma omuntu, omuntu oyo afuna abulwadde bw'embwa obwo.
Obubonero.
Obumu ku bubonero bw’obulwadde buno bwe buno wammanga: omusujja n’okujigiza ewakoseddwa era nga obubonero buno bugobererwa n’obulala nga okutya amazzi, okusanyuukirira okususse, okufuna obuzibu mu kwekyusa, okubuzaabuzibwa n’obulala bungi. Oluusi n’okufa nakwo kubaamu oluvannyuma lw'ebbanga eriri wakati w’omwezi ogumu okutuuka n'esatu. oluvannyuma lw’okulumwa embwa endwadde oba etali ngeme newankubadde obudde bw’okufuniramu obubonero buno buyinza okukyuka n’ebubaawo mu wiiki emu oba omwaka gumu nga kino kisinzira ku bbanga obusagwa ly’ebutambulira mu mubiri okutuuka ku nsibuko y’obusimu.
Obulwadde bw’embwa busaasaana ng'embwa endwade erumye oba eyagudde ekisolo ekirala oba omuntu. Amalusu agava mu nsolo endwadde nago gasobola okusaasanya obulwadde bw’embwa singa amalusu ago gagenda mu maaso, mu kamwa, oba mu nnyindo. Songa ate emmese tezitera kulumwa bulwadde buno. Akawuka akasaasaanya obulwadde bw’embwa katambulira mu bwongo nga kagoberera obusimu. Obulwadde buno bujjanjabwa oluvannyuma lw’okulaba obubonero obwo waggulu.
Engeri y'okuziyiza obulwadde buno.
Okufuna ekumiro ly’ebisolo n’okugemebwa kw’embwa kukendezeza ku ndwadde y’embwa mu bitundu by’ensi ez'enjawulo. Okugema abantu nga tebannalumwa mbwa ndwadde kiziyiza okufuuna obulwadde buno. So ng'ate okwoza ekifo ekirumiddwa oba ekitakuddwa ne sabbuuni wamu n’amazzi okumala eddakiika kkumi na ttaano kiyinza okuyamba mu kutta obuwuka obumu obusaasaanya ekirwadde kino. Abantu batono abawonye obulwadde bw’embwa oluvannyuma lw’okulaga obubonero ng'era kibawo oluvannyuma lw’obujjanjabi obw'amaanyi obumanyiddwa nga "Milwaukee protocol".
Abantu 24,000 ku 60,000 be bafa obulwadde bw’embwa buli mwaka mu nsi yonna, nga era obulwadde buno buli mu nsi 150 okuggyako mu Australia, Canada, Japan, Amerika n'ebitundu bya Bulaaya eby'Ebugwanjuba.

Embu z'Amannya:
Mu nnimi z'Abantu, n'Oluganda mwe lugwa, mulimu ekiyitibwa embu z'amannya. Embu zonna ziri 23 naye amannya agali mu Luganda gagwa mu mbu 21 ku ezo 23. Awo nno tugamba nti Oluganda lulina embu z'amannya 21.
References.
Ashton et al. (1954) Luganda Grammar. Great Britain: Longmans, Green and Company.

Models of Science Centered Vernacular Development for Black Africa to Learn from:
Engeri ez'enjawulo ez'okukulaakulanya ennimi zaffe mu Sayansi ("Models of Science Centered Language Development")
I am presenting four scientific language development models:
The European Model.
The European model includes languages like English, French, Spanish, Italian, German, Danish, Swiss, Russian, among others. Characteristics of the European Model include:
The East Asian Model.
The East Asian model includes languages like Korean, Japanese, Chinese, among others. In the East Asian model of science centered language development:
The Colonial Model.
In this language model, a colonial language was imposed by the colonialists on the people in the colonized territories as a way of ensuring subservience. People were taught the colonial languages to facilitate the colonial system of divide and rule as well as resource extraction to support the European industries in the absence of industrial capacity in the colonies. It is characterized by:
The Blafrican Model.
"The Blafrican model" is the model that is most suitable for black africa. It is an imitation of the East Asian Model where most scientific concepts are formed with locxal etymologies and from internal sources of words by various techniques like semantic extension, blending, compounding, derivation, among others. 
This is a decolonization model, spearheaded by a brilliant African , Muwanga Charles, in order to mitigate the negative effects of learning and teaching science in foreign languages which leads to perpetual intellectual dependence and retrogressive intellectual development of children in the Blafrican societies. 
The Blafrican model is based on the understanding that:
Mr. Muwanga Charles argues that in order to prepare our vernaculars for use in Double Exposure Education(DEED), we need to ensure that:
Etymologies for technical terms need to be the same for all languages because we live in different situations and environments. For example, when I was forming the concept for a “cylinder “, I based myself on the shape of our local mortar called “ekinu” or “enkinu” in Luganda. “Ekinu” is like a “round tin” that has two parallel bottoms of bases that are circular. So I came up with the concepts “enkinu “or “enkunu”, which are blend words from the Luganda phrase “enkula ey’ekinu’ (mortar shaped) to form the geometrical concept “enkinu” (cylinder in) or enkunu (cylinder out), which are now the Luganda concepts for “cylinder”.
The sound of the phrase “technical term” is itself intimidating and indeed it dupes many African academicians, intellectuals, and terminologists to think that “technical” connotes “make difficult to comprehend” or “make difficult to grasp”. 
No!! Why it is called a technical term is because of its reference to a unique area of scientific knowledge in science. If you are a Luganda speaker, compare the following Luganda word phrases:
Which of the two better brings out the meaning in the English phrase “electric current”. 
I am not disregarding the contribution of the proponent of the first concept but I think “omugendo gw’amasannyalaze is more inherently obvious to a Luganda speaker because in the latter both the words in the phrase are existing Luganda words yet “omumeeme” must have been derived from “Umeme”, Swahili for “electricity”. "Omugendo" refers to any movement , even if it is movement of fluids.
A more appropriate word would be “omugendo” (movement of anything, whether it is a fluid or not), which by semantic extension gives us “omugendo gw’amasannyalaze”, electric current. I have also read of “obugububi obumeeme” in contrast to “ekigugubiro ky’amasannyalaze” for “electric resistance”. Which of the two is more obvious, more understandable in translation? 
The indispensables of an intellectual Language
For Luganda language , the first category of must-have words of an intellectual language are:
The prefix “entaba” denotes “interaction” of people. Note that entabamuriro (combustion) denotes interactive action between air and fuel to power a vehicle or a machine.
One necessary concept for an upcoming language of science is the concept of “system”, to help the natives develop the idea of “an organized whole made up of parts that are interrelated”. This is very important to show how machines (ennyanguyirizi) function and the basis of mechanics (ekitambuzo). In Luganda, a system is referred to as “ensengekera” from “ensengeka eyemalirira” (self preserving arrangement). 
Any intellectual language must have concepts that enable its speaker to look at matter not as massive objects but as a system, having subsystems with numerous building blocks, the atom and its subparts. Below is the structure of the hydrogen atom (atomu ya ayidologyeni also referred to as kitondekamazzi in scientific Luganda. The structure of the atomu (Obuzimbe bwa atomu) is what makes us refer to chemistry as essomabuzimbe in Luganda. 
“Essomabuzimbe” has to do with the study of the structure of matter. Below is the “obuzimbe” (structure) of “akaziba” or “atomu” (atom) of “ayidologyeni” or “kitondekamazzi” (hydrogen, water producer)) in Luganda.
In Plural akaziba (luganda for atom) becomes “obuziba” (atoms) but it is also borrowed, adopted and adapted as “atomu” (atom).
In “essomabiramu”, Luganda for biology, a modern language must be able to name the three major branches of biology, that is, essomabulamu bw’ensolo (animal biology), essomabulamu bw’ebimera (plant biology), and essomabulamu obusirikitu (micro biology). In most African societies, it was not known that there are “microscopic organisms”. 
In Luganda “micro-organisms” are referred to as “obulamu obusirikitu”, which require a microscope which is referred to as “enzimbulukusa” (endaga ezimbulukusa obusirikitu). “Obulamu obusirikitu” (microbs) include “bbakitiiriya” (bacteria), “vayiraasi” (virus), polotozowa (protozoa), olufungi (fungus), among others.
An intellectualized language must have concepts to explain that the building blocks of matter which are called “obutoffalikazimbakintu” (not obutaffaalikazimbakintu) are the atoms, which are called “atomu” in Luganda. The atomu also has its building blocks (obutoffaalikazimbatomu) that are called subatomic particles which we call “obutonniinya” (obutono ennyo). These include “obusannyalazo” (electrons), “obukontanyo” or “konta” or “obukonta” (protons) and “nampawengwa” or “nampa “(neutrons).
Apart from “obutonniinya” (subatomic particles named above), there are building blocks of the subatomic particles, konta and nampawengwa. These are refered to as “obutinniinya” (obutini ennyo), “elementary particles” of the atom. Note the difference between “obutonniinya” (subatomic particles) and “obutinniinya” (elementary particles). 
Note that in “essomabiramu” (biology), we also have “obutaffaali” (not obutoffaali of chemistry) for life cells as well as “obuzaaluo” or ‘enzaaluzo” (genes) and “obusirigiinya” (chromosomes). Then by blending, from the Luganda “atomu”, we have formed the concepts of vatomu (ion), vatopo (cation) and vatone (anion) as well as vampa or vampawengwa for isotope. The prefix “va-“indicates motion taking place within the atom. In scientific Luganda we can talk of ebireetamaanyi for carbohydrates, ebyassava for fats, ebizimbamubiri for proteins, and vitamiini for vitamins, enkoggona (ensolo ezrina ebikoggo) for vertabrates and enkoggote (ensolo na tezirina bikoggo) for invertebrates as well as “luyonsa” for “mammals”. We can talk of “ekikula” or “sipiisa” for a ‘species’ or “ebikula” (for species when used as plural). This should note be confused with “enkula” (mathematical shape, figure).
The science of engineering is about building structures or machine systems and their subsystems as well as making genetic innovations using the laws of science. In Luganda “engineering” is referred to as “ekinonoozo”, which is about designing and building systems by specialists known as “abanonooza” (engineers). Engineers (abanonooza) apply the laws of science and mathematics to design and build ennyanguyirizi (machines) or structures. Ennyanguyirizi is also known as “ekyanguyirizi” in Luganda because it simplifies work. 
Still, it is important that our Blafrican languages have the concept of “theory” which in Luganda is refered to as “ekigereeso” from the Luganda verb “okugereesa” (to theorize, to guess). Unlike English, in Luganda we use the word “omugereeso” to mean a mathematical theory and “eggereeso” to refer to a “theorem. So we can talk of eggereeso lya Payisoggolaasi (the Pythagoras theorem) but in Luganda literature “olugereeso” means “a myth”, olugewukano is “irony” and ekigewukano is Luganda for “ironical statement”. Get the difference!
Scientifically speaking what distinguishes “the scientific community” (entababuvo ya sayansi) from non scientists is the fact that the scientists base the search for knowledge on the scientific method” which in Luganda we call “akalombolombo ka sayansi”.
“Akalombolombo ka sayansi” begins with a question on a natural phenomenon. We call a “natural phenomenon” or “natutural phenomena”“kalonda w’obutonde”. In plural natural phenomena is still collectively referred to as “kalonda w’obutonde”. The question on nature is followed by making a “hypothesis” which can be referred to as "ekisinziiro"(ekyo kw'osinziira) in scientific Luganda. "Ekisinziiro" is simply statement trying to answer a scientific question. 
Next is the act of “validating” (okukakasa ekiteeberezo” by trial and testing. Testing is what we call “engezeso” in a process known as experimentation or okunoonya enkakaso in Luganda. Any intellectual language must have the concept for “statement” which is “ekigambululo” from the Luganda verb “okugamba” (to say or to state). You can now talk of ekigambululo kya police (police statement), ekigambululo ky’ebyensimbi (financial statement), among others as you will learn from this book.
Those concepts are necessary to make a mother tongue an intellectual language but the beginning of turning a cultural language into a language of science must be to build the three basic concepts of “force “ which is “empalirizo” in Luganda, “energy” which is “amasoboza”, and “motion” which is “okuva ” in Luganda.
Lastly, you cannot count a language among the intellectual languages without the “-logy words” which we call “essoma-words” or some other words for “the various fields” of study in vernacular. In Luganda we are now able to talk of:
among others.

The necessary standards for scientific concepts formation for the Black african Languages:
IALI NGO was authorized by terminologist Charles Muwanga to post this article from his terminology research work on Luganda Wikipedia for free public consumption.
The necessary standards for scientific concepts formation in the black African Languages.
Ensure that for every key concept you wish to build, all the necessary sub-concepts are also in place for meaningful use. For instance, coming up with the concept “omukutule”, Luganda for “fraction” is a step forward but without the sub concepts of factorization, factors, multiples, nominator, denominator, LCM” or GCF, you can’t carry out any calculation to do with addition or subtraction of fractions in your vernacular until after you have developed the sub-concepts necessary for fractional calculations. 
In Luganda we have come up with - concepts like “okulambulula ennamba (to factor numbers), ennambuluzo (a factor or factors), enkubise (multiple), enkubisa (coefficient), Enkubise Eyawamu (Common Factor), “Enkubise Eyawamu Esembayo” or “EESE” (Lowest Common Multiple (LCM), Nambuluzo Eyawamu (Common Factor), and the concept of NESI, an acronym for “Nambuluzo Eyawamu Esingayo” or “Greatest Common Factor”(GCF), Kinnawansi Eyawamu (Common Denominator), among others. 
(ii) In using the techniques of blending, compounding, semantic extension, eponyms, among others, priority should be given to the internal sources (ensibuko ezomunda) within a given vernacular. 
In terminology development, it is always best to form words by blending, compounding, eponyms or semantic extension. For example, the Luganda concept for “being proportional” is “okugendana”, formed by semantic extension. From “okugendana + okugaana okusisinkana” is formed, by blending, the mathematical concept of “okugendaggana ne”, meaning “to be parallel to”. “Layini” is a loan word meaning “line”, which is also translated as “olukoloboze” or “omusittale”. So “Layini ezigendaggana” denotes “Parallel Lines”
For instance, in reproductive biology, in Luganda, Luganda been using the word “enkwaso”, to refer to the “bonding staff of life called “sperms” which is also used to mean “chemical bond” in chemistry but to clearly separate the concepts of “sperm” and “chemical bond”, the sperms are now baptized empakiso derived from the Luganda verb “okuwakisa”, to make pregnant or “okuwaka”, to impregnate, which is in every way distinct from “enkwaso” (chemical bonding). 
In Luganda, “semen”, the watery stuff, in which the sperms swim, is now called “empugiso’. Empugiso, Luganda for “semen” is derived from the Luganda verb “okuwuga” which means “to swim”. Empugiso etymologically means ‘that which enables something, in this case, the sperms, to swim to its target. 
The name “Muwanga” in this case has “solar gravity” connotations, derived from its etymological meaning, the verb “okuwanga” meaning “to be the cause of.., to fix something in its position”. Solar gravity is the cause of the pull that keeps the planets (enkulungo) in their respective orbits around the sun. 
Gravity, essikirizo, in Luganda, is explained as a type of “centripetal force”, empalirizo esikira mu makkati, the force that pulls towards the center. When it is acted on by another forces that tends to free the center , the centrifugal force, which is empalirizo eyabulira oba eyewaggula ku makakti in Luganda, the resulting effect is the science that keeps the planets in their. It is a result of “opposing forces”, empalirizo ezisikira ku mpuyi bbiri eza kikontana.
Essikirizo for gravity as ensikirizo is for magnetic attraction. The concept of essikirizo is derived from the concept of ensikirizo (attraction) because essikirizo means ensikirizo ennene (strong attraction). When we blende the words ensikirizo ennene” we get the blend word “essikirizo” for “gravity”. Ensikirizo (attraction) is itself derived from the ordinary Luganda verb “okusikiriza” (to attract, to entice) as that which takes place between members of the opposite sex.
One other concept separated from word is that of the “atmosphere” which in English refers to both the atmospheres of planets with life as well as the atmospheres of the planets which don’t hold the conditions for life. To separate the concepts from the word, I have called the atmospheres of the planets which have conditions for life like the planet earth, “nampewo”, because it is a combination of gases which make up the air required for life (empewo ey’obulamu). In fact “nampewo is a blend word from the phrase “nakazaala w’empewo” ey’obulamu.
Muwanga has called the atmospheres of planets that lack conditions for life, “namikka” meaning “mere gases (mikka bukka) that don’t have the ingredients that make “life sustaining air” (empewo).
Lastly but not least, to separate concepts from word , Muwanga has formed the twin concepts of “okutonda” (the act of creation by God) and “okutondeka” (the act of producing, manufacturing or to creation by man). The word “to create” is used more for “the creative act of God” and less for “the creative act of man”. 
I have separated the two concepts by coming up with the Luganda concept of “okutondeka” (to produce, production, to manufacture, manufacturing, to create) to refer to “the creative act of man”. “Okutondeka” is a blend word from “okutonda ebikoleka”omuntu “(creation by man from the resources provided by God), referring to production or manufacturing. Okutondeka can also refer to creation of “mental” or “abstract” ideas. Okutondeka thus refers to both the verb to produce, to manufacture and the noun, production, or the process of manufacturing.
It ordinarily means production or manufacturing of goods and commodities made from the natural resources created by God for use by man. The concept of “okutondeka” is formed by blending the words okutonda + ebikoleka (omuntu).
The noun derived from the act of “okutondeka”, “entondeka” (way or techniques of manufacturing) is the Luganda concept for “manufacturing technology”. We can hence talk of:
• Entondeka ya kompyuta (computer manufacturing technology).
• Entondeka y’emotoka (automobile manufacturing technology).
So we can now talk of “okutondeka ebyamaguzi” to mean “to create, to manufacture, or to produce goods and commodities or creation, production, or manufacturing of goods and commodities.
In intellectual Luganda, we shouldn’t say “okutonda ebyamaguzi” because the word “kutonda” is a divine act of only God. “Okutondeka ebyamaguzi” simply means “the manufacturing or production of goods” or “to manufacture or to produce goods”. Don’t forget that “entondeka y’ekintu’ refers to the manufacturing technology of something. That is scientific Luganda you must know.

Using Ebifundiwazo (Acronyms) to form scientific concepts in Luganda:
“Ekifundiwazo” (acronym) is a blend from the words in the phrase “ekigambo ekyatulwa mu bufunze bw’ensirifu” (initialized word spoken out as a full word). “Okufundiwaza” (acronymizing) is a word formation process which is a subtype of blending. Did you know that the word “acronym” itself is an abbreviation? 
An acronym in full is: “A Common Representation of Names you must shorten”. It is said that the English word “NEWS” is an acronym from initials or abbreviations of the words “North” abbreviated (N), “East” abbreviated (E),“West” abbreviated (W) and South abbreviated (S). The implication is that information broadcast by media houses should come from all the directions.
Other Important English acronyms which we cannot avoid using in Scientific Luganda are “LASER” and “RADAR”. “LASER” is an acronym for "Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation” in Luganda we simply call it “Ekyongezamasoboza ga Kitangaala” whose acronym is “EKYOKI”. 
“Amasoboza” is energy, “Ekyongezamasoboza” is amplification and “ekitangaala” is light. This is made possible by what we call “okwongeza enfulumya y’emigendo gy’olubugumu”, Luganda for “stimulated emission of radiation”. Laser-guided bomb is “bbomu egoberera amasoboza g’ekitangaala” or “Bbomu y’ekyoki”.
“Radar” is an acronym for “Radio Detection and Ranging”, in Luganda I have called it “Ekiketto eky’Amayengo ga Leediyo”. The acronym is “EKIKENGO”. So the Luganda concept for “RADAR” is “EKIKENGO”. Ekiketto kiva mu kikolwa kya kuketta (to detect).
Kino kyeyambisibwa okuketta, okubaza obuwanvu n’okukuba ebifaananyi b’ebiddukira mu bwengula ng’ennyonyi oba enkuba mu bwengula nga weyambisa “amayengo ga lediyo” (radio waves). Amayengo ga lediyo ag’amaanyi gafulumizibwa olwo ori gwe gatuukako n’awuliriza okufuna amaddannyuma (reflected echoes). Generally you can see that an acronym is a set of abbreviations formed by the initials of two or more words. These components may be:
I. Individual letters. Like the letters making up a word such as the Luganda math word “NESI “(for English GCF) or EESE the Luganda math word for English LCM. “NESI” in full is Nambuluzo Eyawamu Esingayo (Greatest Common Factor) and EESE in full is Enkubise Eyawamu Esembayo (Lowest Common Multiple).
II. Parts of words. This makes acronyms closely related to blends in some instances. A good example is the Luganda concept of EKKAMUSO an acronym from the Words “Endaga ya Kkala za Musoke” which is Luganda for “the Rainbow Spectrum”. So is the acronym EKYOKI (Rasor) from the words “Ekyongezamasoboza ga Kitangaala” and the acronym “EKIKENGO” (RADAR) from the Luganda words “Ekiketto eky’Amayengo ga Leediyo”.

Ebinnalinnya(Eponyms) as a technique for formation of Luganda scientific concepts:
IALI NGO has been authorized by terminologist Charles Muwanga to post this article from his Luganda scientific terminology research work for free public consumption.
Ekinnalinnya (epynom) simply means “ekigambo ekibbuddwa mu linnya ly’omuntu (a word formed from the name of a real or fictitious person). The Luganda concept for rainbow, “Kkala za Musoke” is an eponym and so are the days of the week in Luganda. 
We can talk of “Endaga ya Kkala za Musoke” or Ekkamuso (rainbow colours) named from an ancient Buganda researcher on the phenomenon called “rainbow”. The English names of the planets (enkulungo) in our solar system are all eponyms named after the Roman gods and goddesses. I have likewise opted to attempt to name the planets in Luganda after some of the great thinkers of ancient Buganda given below:
Position from the sun Planet Etymology 
1 Kiwanuka (Mercury) Ancient researcher on the cause of the lightening 
2 Ddungu (Venus) Ancient hunter and animal researcher from Mabira Kyaggwe
3 Ensi (Earth) This was borrowed from the English word “Earth” 
4 Mukasa (Mars) Ancient researcher on the movement of winds on lake Victoria (Nalubaale)
5 Kisuule (Saturn) 17th century Royal gunsmith for Kabaka Mutesa I and Mwanga II
6 Kibuuka (Jupiter) Ancient military strategist and warrior
7 Nagaddya (Uranus) Ancient medicine woman
8 Ggulu (Neptune) Ancient researcher on the universe (the heavens)
9 Nakayima (Pluto) Ancient Medicine woman
Our sun, “Enjuba Muwanga”, is also an eponym because it is named after the ancient Ganda Thinker, Muwanga, who was himself a student of Wanga and one of the ancient Philosophers of Buganda.

Adopting and adapting English abbreviations in Scientific Luganda:
IALI NGO has been authorized b y terminologist Charles Muwanga to post this article from his Luganda scientific terminology research on Luganda wikipedia for free public consumption.
Enfundiwazo (Abbreviations)
The concept of “enfundiwazo” (abbreviations) is from the Luganda word “okufunza ebigambo” ( to abbreviate) meaning using initials of a word.
Abbreviations are formed by the initial letters of a word or phrase. “Enfundiwazo are mainly used in written language, not spoken language. In the chemistry of Luganda, we are borrowing almost all the chemical elements and their abbreviated chemical symbols from the chemical names adopted and adapted from English.
In all our blafrican languages, abbreviations of the elements of the periodic table of elements are very useful in scientific discourse. The borrowed “Namunigina z’Amawanga ez’Ebipimo” (International System of Units) in Luganda are likewise abbreviated for convenience in calculations and publications.
See tables below:
Nigi (Units)
loanword Ensirisiwazo
Miita (meter) M
kirogulaamu (kilogram) Kg
Sikonda (seconds) S
Ampaya (ampire) A
Kaluviini (Kalvin) K
Yinsi (inches) Yi
Fuuti (feet) Ft
Yaadi (yards) Yd
Mairo (mile) Ml
Ggalani (golon) Gn
Sentimita (centmeter) Sm
Take note of the following units of measurements below:
There are also nigi ezibbule (derived units) which are also abbreviated as follows:
Ekipimo(Measurement) Nigi/Unigi/Nigina/
Namunigina (units) Akabonero(symbol)
Obugazi or Obwagagavu (Area) Miita ya kyebiriga (square meter ) m2
Obubangirivu (Volume) Miita ya kyesatuza (cubic meter) m3
Embiro n’eng’enda(speed and velocity) Miita buli sikonda(meter per second) m/s
Entebenta (acceleration) Miita buli sikonda eya kyebiriga (meter per square second ) m/s2
Omuwendo gw’ejjengo(Wave number) Miita eya kasulike(reciprocal meter) m-1
Obukwafuwavu bw’enzitoya (mass density) Kirogulaamu buli mita aya kyesatuza (kilogram per cubic meter) kg/m3
Obubangirivu obwesonjovu(specific volume) Miita ya kyesatuza buli kirogulaamu(Cubic meters per kilogram) m3/kg
Obukwafuwavu bw’omugendo gw’amasannyalaze(current density) Ampaya buli miita eya kyebiriga (Ampires per square meter A/m2
Eryanyi l y’ekyebulungulo kya magineeti (magnetic field strength Ampaya buli miita (ampire per meter A/m
Abbreviations used on the “Endagabwolekero” (Geographical Compass)
Other abbreviations necessary in any vernacular include those used on the Compass Rose (Endagabwolekero). They are not borrowed but abbreviated directly from Luganda words :
1) BK (Bukiikakkono), the Luganda equivalent of N for North
2) BD (Bukiikaddyo), the Luganda equivalent of S for South).
3) BV (Buvanjuba), the Luganda equivalent of E for East.
4) BG (Bugwanjuba), the Luganda equivalent of W for West
5) BKoBV (Bukiikakkono owa Buvanjuba) the Luganda equivalent of NE for “North East”.
6) BKoBG (Bukiikakkono owa Bugwanjuba) the Luganda equivalent of NE for North West
7) BDoBV (Bukiikaddyo owa Buvanjuva) the Luganda equivalent of SE for South East.
8) BDOBG (Bukiikaddyo owa Bugwanjuba) the Luganda equivalent of SW for South West.
Abbreviations of the elements of the Periodic Table
The Luganda elements of the periodic table of chemical elements and their abbreviations or symbols are almost all borrowed from the one of English. For ease of uniformity, all the vernacular abbreviations should remain as they are in English in all our blafrican languages.

Luganda scientific concepts formed by semantic extension:
Okugaziya amakulu (Semantic extension)
In terminology, you can form a new concept by broadening the meaning of an existing word or phrase in your vernacular, which word is close in meaning to the foreign concept you intend to adopt in order to accommodate a new but indirectly or closely related meaning. For example:

Luganda Scientific Concepts formed by Derivation from affixes:
IALI NGO has been authorized by terminologist Charles Muwanga to post this article from his Luganda scientific terminology research work on Luganda Wikipedia for free public consumption.
Okukozesa “Obuwango” 
The addition and subtraction of prefixes and suffixes is an important technique for the formation of new concepts in a vernacular, particularly chemistry. In Luganda, “okuwanga” (to affix) refers to the process of derivation that involves adding what is referred to as “akawango” (a derivational affix). “Akawango” is attached to the root of a word to create a new concept. Obuwango (affixes) include obuwango obusookeso (prefixes) and obuwango obuvannyuma (suffixes). 
Prefixes 
Prefix Meaning
Obu….. the act of 
Obwe….. Characterized by or inclined to
Essoma….. Study of 
En….. Appearance of or away of doing something
Omu….. Number value or a human being 
Eki…… Drawing of... or mathematics of …
Ekidda….. Reverse or negative or forward or positive
Enta…… Without change, without end
Obwa…… Practice of..,…ism
Va……. Refers to “motion”
Olu……. Refers to a story, narrative, language form in literature
Kolo….. Chemical name prefix….chlori….
Kali….. Chemical element prefix chloro…
Ayidolo… Prefix for “hydra..”
Kipo… Prefix for hypo…
Pero… Prefix for per…
Emu- Luganda for prefix “Mono-“ meaning one atom
Bbiri- Luganda for prefix “di-“ meaning two atoms
Satu- Luganda for prefix “Tri-“
Nnya- Luganda for preix “Tetra-“
Tano- Luganda for prefix “Penta-“
kaaga- Luganda for prefix “Hexa-“
sanvu- Luganda for prefix “Hepta-“
naana- Luganda for prefix “Octa-“
Mwenda- Luganda for prefix “Nona-“
Kumi- Luganda for prefix “Deca- “
Ayidologyeni- Luganda for element “Hydro
Suffixes
Obuwango obuvannyuma(suffixes) can be added to existing words to create new concepts of science :
Suffix Meaning
…lula Undo 
…wamu together or common to
…gana Proportional to, corresponding with,
…ggana Same distance apart without ever meeting
….wo To put in place, to produce, to create
…logiya Study of.., filed of study
…wala To become to change into
….nyo Indicates a change from a verb to a noun
….o Indicates a change from a verb to a noun
…..ayidi Luganda for chemical compound suffix ….ide
……eti Luganda for chemical compound suffix ….ate
….ayiti Luganda for chemical compound suffix ….ite
Ayidolo.. Luganda for hydro..
……edi Luganda for Chemical compound suffix for ….ade
…..okisayidi Luganda for Suffix meaning ..oxide
Weetegereze bino ebiddako n'eriiso eryogi awamu n'obwongo obwogi :
(i) Obuwango obusookeso 
a) Obu-“ means “the act of”
b) Obwe-means “ characterized by” or “inclined to”
c) Essoma-means “study of …”.compare with “-logia”.
e) Omu-refers to a “number value” (omuwendo) in Mathematics if not a reference to a human being (omuntu).
f) Eki-refers to “ekikube “(drawing) or “ekibalangulo kya.”(Mathematics of...)
g) “Ekidda-“indicates negativity (reverse) or positivity ( forward movement) in math.
h) “Enta-“ without change, without end ,math constant in Luganda math 
i) “Obwa-“means…. “practice of” or,”….ism”
j) “Va-“indicates motion. The root “va” indicates “Motion” (=okuva)
k) ”Ayidologyeni -“prefix for hydrogen compound e.g. ayidologyeni fololayidi (hydrogen fluoride)
l) “Ayidolo” Prefix for “hydro-“e.g. ayidolokololikasidi (Hydrochloric acid).
 (ii) Obuwango obuvannyuma 
 
(i) -lula” which denotes “undo”, “to analyse“, “to factor numbers”
(ii) “-wamu” which denotes “together” or “common to” 
(iii) ”-gana” which denotes “corresponding with” or, “together” or proportional to or related to.
(iv) “-ggana” which denotes “same distance apart but never to meet”
(v) “-wo” which denotes to put in place e.g.“okutondawo” (to Create), to complete
(vi) “-logia”, the study of , the science of, field of study
(vii) “-wala” denotes “to become “ or “ to change into”
(viii) “-nyo” and “-o” words. Indicates that these are nouns 
(ix) “-lo” refers to a statement, or explanation e.g. ekigambululo or ekinnyonnyolo
(x) “-ayiti” is a suffix for a chemical name equivalent of “-ite” e.g. nayitulayiti NO2- for nitrite NO2- 
When translating a chemical suffix (akawango akavannyuma), the end part of a chemical name needs careful attention. In chemistry there is an immense difference between the "ide", "ate" and "ite" suffixes. In chemistry, the English suffix “…ide” becomes “…ayidi” in Luganda; “….ate” becomes “…eeti” and “…ite” becomes “ayiti”.
(a). Ekisooka, akawango akalaga endagakintu (elements). Akawango akavannyuma "-ayidi" (-ide) kalaga nti eyo ndagakintu(element). Ebyokulabirako Salufayidi S2-, (sulfide S2-), nayitulayidi N3- (nitride N3-) ne Fosifayidi P3- (Phosphide P3) okujjako “ayidolokisayidi” OH- eno nga mu Lungereza eba - (hydroxide OH- ) ne “kyanayidi” CN- n’eba cyanide CN- 
Derivations from Obuwango Obusookeso 
i) “Eby-“
The prefix “eby--“ordinarily means “of ...” but technically denotes “ebyenjifiriza n’ebikolebwa ebya…” (education and activities in the field of…”.We can hence talk of ebyenjigiriza, that is, “, to do with training or teaching. Using the prefix “eby- to refer to “ebyenjigiriza n’ebikolebwa ebya” (education and the activities in the field of.), various concepts can be formed as follows:
(a) Ebyobufuna (political economy). The concept is derived from the words “ebyenjigiriza n’ebikolebwa eby’embeera y’ebyobufuzi n’ebyenfuna” or “embeera y’ebyobufuzi n’ebyenfuna” (education in the field of political economy).
(b) Ebyamalimiro (agriculture) denoting “ebyenjigiriza n’ebikolebwa ku malimiro” (education on farm activities). That is the etymological meaning of “ebyamalimiro”.”Eddimiro” is Luganda for a farm. In plural it becomes “amalimiro (farms). Mu “ebyamalimiro” mulimu:
• Ebyobulimi (crop farming)
• Ebyobulunzi (animal farming)
• Ebyebibira (forestry farming)
• Ebyebimuli (floriculture)
(c) Ebyobunyukufu (Literature). This is from the phrase “ebyenjigiriza n’ebikolebwa eby’obunyukufu” (education and activities in the field of Literacy). Obunyukufu is Luganda for “literacy”. Ebyobunyukufu is “literature”. Obunyukufu (literacy) comes from the Luganda word “ennyukuta’ or “ennukuta” (letter). We can also talk of:
• “Obunyukufu” or “Obunukufu” (literacy)
• Ebyobunyukufu or Ebyobunukufu (literature)
Unlike English, in Luganda we make a distinction of oral and written literature by separating the concepts. Oral literature is “ekigambulolo” (stated by word of mouth) but “written literature” is “ebinyukuto” or “ebinukuto” (as written down). A “Police statement” and a “Bank statement”are however, even after they are put down in writing, refered to as ‘ekigambululo kya poliisi” and “ekigambululo kya bbanka “respectively. We can talk of :
• Ebinukuto ebiyiiyirize (fiction literature). Bino binukuto ebiteesigamye ku fakikya.
• Ebinukuto ebya fakikya (factual literature) e.g. Ebinukuto ebya sayansi (science literature) or ebyafaayo(history)
(d) Ebyobulamu (health). This refers to “ebyenjgiriza n’ebikolebwa “okukuuma n’okujanjaba obulamu” (education/training as well as the activities in the area of health).
(e) Ebyamakolero (industry). This refers to “training and the activities in the area of manufacturing (okutondeka)”
ii) “Ekidda-“
This prefix denotes forward or backward movement. Examples:
• “Ekiddannyuma” (negative, reverse) 
• “Ekiddamaaso” (positive, forward movement)
Examples: “Ennamba za kiddannyuma” (negative numbers) or “ennamba za kiddamaaso“(positive numbers). But we can also borrow and adopt these mathematics concepts directly from English as follows: “Ennamba za negatiivu” (negative numbers or “ennamba za pozitiivu” (positive numbers). 
iii) “Enta-“ 
This prefix means “without”. For example:
 Entakyuka (without change, mathematical constant) 
 Entakoma (without stopping, mathematical infinity) 
More examples:
• Omugendo ogw’entakoma (continuous motion)-
• Okuva okw’entakoma (continuous motion);
• Entamanyika (existing without being known, the unknown, variable, enkuumakifo).
• Entagenda (without movement, without motion)
• Entagenda (statics in physics)
• Amasannyalaze ag’entagenda (Static electricity)
iv) “Obwa-“ :
This denotes “practice of” or “exhibiting ...” .or “...sm”. 
Examples:
a) Obwakatonda (practice of godliness, divinity) 
b) Obwakalimagezi (the practice of intelligence, human intelligence, exhibiting intelligence)
c) Obwannakalyakaani (the practice of socialism, Socialism) 
d) Obwasitakange (the practice of capitalism, Capitalism)
e) Obwannalukalala (reactionalism) 
f) Obwannakyemalira (practice of dictatorship, Dictatorship)
g) Obwannakyewa (practice of volunteerism, voluntarism)
Note that omugezi or omuntu omugezi translates“a wise person” and “kalimagezi” translates “intelligent man”. Amagezi translates “wisdom”but “obwakalimagezi“ translates “the practice of intellegence or intelligence). Generally, the various concepts associaated with the word “amagezi” (wisdom) are :
a) Obwakalimagezi (intelligence). 
“Obwakalimagezi” is a compound word whose root is “amagezi” (wisdom). This root is combined with a prefix “obwa…”(practice of) to produce the concept of “obwakalimagezi”(intelligence).
b) Omuntu-kalimagezi (intelligent man).
c) Koma-sapiyensa (Homo sapiens). 
It is a loan-word borrowed from the english “homo sapiens”. (wise man). Koma-sapiyensa can also be translated “Omuntu kalimagezi”
d) Ensolo kalimagezi (intelligent animal ). 
This is a concept of two seperated compound words, ensolo (animal) and kalimagezi (intelligent being, a genius). The synonyms are “omuntu kalimagezi” (intelligent man) or “kalimagezi” (intelligent man) or omuntu omugezi (wise man).
e) Omulengera (the human “mind). 
This concept is formed by blending of the words “omwoyo ogukulengeza” (the spirit that illuminates) to get“omulengera”(the soul of foresight, the spirit that foresees). “Omulengera” (the mind) is a faculty of the brain that brings about critical thinking, analysis, knowing, understanding and discovery, among others.
f) Nnyoloni (neuron). 
This is a loan-word from the english word “neurons”. Nnyoloni (neurons) are simply the building blocks of the brain. The Luganda word “nnyoloni” is pronounced starting with “nnyo..sound and not “nyu..sound” which sounds like “new”. The neurons are determenants of human intelligence and the functioning of “omulengera” (the human mind). The synonym for “nnyoloni”(neuron) is “Obutaffaalikazimbabwongo”(the building blocks of the brain) which is a compoud word made of three words, obutaffaali (cells), obuzimba (to build), and the brain (obwongo). Obutaffaalikazimbabwongo are the neurons.
g) Ekipimo ky’Obwakalimagezi (EkkyO). 
The Luganda concept for“Intelligence Quostient” (IQ) is “Ekipimo ky’Obwakalimagezi” abreviated as “EkkyO”. It is a coumpound of seperated words “ekipimo (measure), kya (of) and obwakalimagezi (intelligence).
h) Okukozesa obwongo (reasoning). 
“Okukozesa obwongo”(reasoning) is formed from two words “okukozesa (to make use of) and “obwongo”(the brain). The synonyms for okukozesa obwongo would be “okusengeka ebirowoozo (logic). The process of “okukozesa obwongo”(reasoning) includes okulowooza (thinking), okwefumiitiriza (critical thinking), okwekenneenya or okulambulula (analysis), okukuba-ekifaaananyo (imagination), okujjukira (memorisation), okusengeka ensonga (logic), n’okugoba ensonga (dialectical thinking) which is also called “okulowooza okwa mugobansonga” (dialectical thinking). 
i) Okulambika ebirowoozo (inductive reasoning). 
“Okulambika ebirowoozo” (inductive reasoning) is a concept formed by semantic expansion. Ordinarily it means “to argue by showing sense” of your argument.
j) Okulambulula Ebirowoozo (Deductive Reasoning).
k) Okusengeka Ebirowoozo (Logic)
l) Endowooza Esengeka ebirowoozo (Logical Thinking)
m) Entondeka Y’ebikole (Production Of Commodities)
n) Kagezimunyu (Genius)
o) Mulowooza (Cerebrum)
q) Sekalowooleza (male thinker)
r) Nakalowooleza (Female Great thinker )
s) Firosofa oba Forosoofa (Philosophy)
t) Omufirosoofa (Philosopher)
u) Basekalowooleza Ab’edda (Ancient Thinkers)
v) “ Obu-1“ :
a) Obutujju (terrorism, act of terrorism) 
b) Obufere (act of false pretense, coning ) 
c) Obunyunyunsi (exploitation, act of exploitation)
d) Obunyukufu (skill or act of using letters, literacy)
e) Obunukufu (same as above, literacy)
The concept of obunyukufu or obunukufu (literacy) has been derived from the Luganda word “ennyukuta” or “ennukuta” (Luganda for “letter”). More words have been derived from the new concept of “obunyukufu/obunukufu”. These include:
a) Omunyukufu (omuntu omunukufu) (literate person)
b) Omunyukufu owa kibogwe (semi-literate person).
vi) “Obu –2 means “state of…”.
It is also used to form nouns from verbs e.g.
• Obukambivu (viscosity) 
• Obukwatufu (viscosity) 
• Obukwafu (thickness).
• Obukwafuwazu (density) 
vii) “Obwe- (denotes condition of, trait of, shape of )e.g.
• Obwenkanya (justice, justly) 
• Obwesimbu (trustworthy, geometrical height )
• Obwekulungirivu (spherical shape )
• Obwetoloovu (circumference of a circular shape )
• Obweraliikirivu (worry)
viii) Essoma-denotes “study of..”, “science of…, field of study, -logy “e.g.
• Essomampimo (Geometry, Study of Geometry)
• Essomansi (Geography
• Esomanjazi (Geology)
• Essomabutonde /Essomabuzimbe (Physics, Science of Nature)
• Essomabuziba (Chemistry)
• Essomampuyisatu (Trigonometry)
• Essomabiramu (Biology)
• Essomabutonzi (Divinity)
• Essomabinyunyunsi (Parasitology)
• Essomaddagala (Medicine)
• Essomabuyambi (Nursing)
See the list of essoma-words at end of this book.
ix) En-words 1
En-denotes “the way of doing something”, “the means or way of doing something” e.g.
• Entondeka (technology, how production goes on)
• Entambula (transportation ), 
• Endya (dieting, the way eating is balanced)
• Enkola (policy, the guiding principle)
• Endyennungi (balanced eating),
• Eng’enda (velocity, the way something is moving).
x) En-words 2.”En-”can also be used to derive a noun from a verb e.g.
• Enzitoya (mass) and 
• Enzitoyo (mass) both derived from the verb “okuzitoya” (to give weight to something, to make something heavy) or obuzito (weight).
• Entabaganya (Society) is derived from the verb “okutabaganya” (to socialize, to mediate) or “okutabagana” (to mix with others, to relate with others).
xi) Omu-words. Omu-is used to refer to a human being. Omu-also denotes a number or a value (omuwendo). It is used to derive the mathematics concepts: 
• “Omugerageranyo” (ratio), that is, omuwendo ogugerageranya. Note that “Ekigerageranyo” (rate) has been derived from the Luganda verb “okugerageranya (to compare). And as you know, the English concepts “ratio” and “rate” both have to do with mathematical comparisons.”Ekigerageranyo is from the phrase “ekibalo ekigerageranya ku buli namunigina”.
• “Omukunuukirizo” (estimation) is a derivation from the Luganda verb okukunuukiriza (to aim at, to reach out for).The new mathematical concept of “okuzingako” (to round off) is a derivation from the Luganda word “okuzinga” (to fold). Omukunuukirizo is from the phrase “omuwendo omukunuukirize”.
• Omutonnyeze. The mathematical concept of “omutonnyeze” (decimal number) is a derivation from the Luganda noun “akatonnyeze” (point). When you add the prefix omu-, you get “omutonnyeze” (decimal value, decimal number). Omutonnyeze is from the phrase “omuwendo ogw’akatonnyewze”.
xii) Eki…words. The prefix ‘eki.” denotes “ekibalo kya…” (The mathematics of.) Or “ekikube kya...” (the drawing of …) ” or ekigambululo ekifundiwaze (initialized statement, word). Examples:
• Ekifundiwazo (acronym)
• Ekibalirizo (arithmetic)
• Ekikyusaganyo (transformation)
• Ekifaanaganyo (reflection)
• Ekifaananyo (image)
• Ekyetoloozo (rotation)
• Ekiseetulo (displacement)
• Ekiseetuko (translation)
• Ekikwataganyo (coordinate)
• Ekikwanaganya (mapping diagram)
xii) Va-words.The prefixes “va…”indicates an act of “motion or movement”. For example:
a) The verb ‘oku-va (to move) forms the concept of “motion” by conversion.
b) Vatomu (va + atomu) means ion, an atom which is in a state of motion or movement of electrons, either by loss of electrons or gaining of electrons
c) Vatone (vatomu +negatiiivu) means “anion”. This happens in a situation where there has been gaining of electron leading to a negative atom.
d) Vatopo (vatomu + pozitiivu) means “cat ion”. This happens in a situation where there has been loss of electrons leading to a positive atom.
e) Vampawengwa (va + nampawengwa) or “vampa”is the Luganda concept for “isotope”. “Vampawengwa” (Vampa) is formed when some atoms of the same element lose neutrons (nampawengwa). “Loss of neutrons” or “to loose neutrons”implies” motion or movement of neutrons from some atoms of the same element.
xiii) Olu-words. The prefix “olu-“is used to point at the various literary forms in Luganda’ olu- could mean “olugero lwa…” (The story of) or “olulimi” (language form) as “olugerageranyo” (simile) and “olufaanaganyo” (metaphor)
Obuwango obuvannyuma 
a) “–lula” which denotes “undo” e.g. okulambulula (to factor numbers, to undo composite numbers)
b) “-wamu” which denotes “together” or “common” e.g. “enkubise ey’awamu” (common multiple) endowooza ey’awamu (common thinking, Ideology)
c) ”-na” which denotes “corresponding” or, “together” e.g. “okukolagana” (working together). “Okugendana (to be proportional), “okukwatagana (getting together); okugendagana (to correspond).
d) “-ggana” which denotes (same distance apart but never to meet) e.g.“okugendaggana”(to be parallel)
e) “-wo” which denotes “to put in place” e.g. okutondawo (to create), okutondekawo (to produce), okubajjawo (to put in place a piece of furniture) or Okulimawo (to put in place a garden of )
f) “-logia”, the study of, the science of e.g. tekinologiya
g) “-wala” denotes “to become “Okutondowala” basically means “to become water droplets” which is “condensation”.
h) “-nyo” and “-o” words. Many technical nouns are derived from verbs using the suffix“-nyo” or”-o”. Examples:
 Ekisonjozo (Characteristic)
 Ekinnyonnyozo (Property)
 Omugerageranyo (Ratio)
 Omugeranyo (Average)
 Ekigerageranyo (Rate)
 Ekigeranyo (Quotient)
 Omukendeezo (Discount)
 Omuganyulo (Interest)
 Omuganyulwo (Interest)
 Ensirisowazo (Abbreviation)
 Okusirisiwaza (To abbreviate
 Ekifundiwazo (Acronym)
 Enfundiwazo/ensirisowazo (abbreviation)
 Okufundiwaza (to acrinimize)
Other examples of derived concepts include:
(i) The concepts of “entabaganya” (society) and “entabaganyabantu” (human society) which are derivations from the Luganda verb “okutabagana” (to socialize) or “okutabanganya” (to mediate).
(ii) Okutondeka (to produce, the act of creation by man) and entondeka y’ebikole (production) are derivations from “okutonda” (the act of creation by God) or “okutondeka” (to create, the act of creation by man). In Luganda we can now say that “ensibuko y’obugagga bw’amawanga eri mu “ntondeka ya bikole” (“the source of the wealth of nations is production”.
(iii) The mathematical concepts of “okulambulula namba” (to analyse, to factor numbers) and ennambuluzo (factors of a number) are derivations from the Luganda word “okulambulula” (to explain in detail). From the concept of “okulambulula namba” the following mathematical concepts are derived:
• Namba ennambulukufu (composite numbers)
• Namba ezerambulula (composite numbers)
• Namba ezitali nambulukufu (prime number)
• Namba eziterambulula (prime numbers)
(iv) The mathematical concept of “okugendaggana” (to be parallel,Parallelism) is derived from blending the two Luganda words “okugendana” (to match, to be equal in strength or magnitude, to correspond with) plus “okugaanagana” (but never to meet). Through semantic extension, the meaning of the word “okugendana” is extended to refer to the mathematical concept of “being proportional to” but when combined with the word “okugaanagana” we get the concept “okugendaggana” (to be parallel). Other mathematical concepts derived from this are:
• Empeto ezigagendagana )corresponding angles)
• Okugendana kifuulannenge ( inverse proportionality)
• Layini ezigendaggana (parallel lines)
• Enkoloboze ezigendaggana (parallel lines)
• Emisittale egigendaggana (parallel lines )
• Omugendanyo =Omugendaganyo (proportion)
• Emigendanyo =Emigendaganyo (proportions)
(v) The concepts of kikontana (opposite of) or “ebintu ebya kikontana” (things that are opposite) are derived from the Luganda word “okukontana” (to contradict, to correspond with, to be the opposite of, to be contrary to). Other derivations from the word “okukontana” include:
• Obumu bw’ebikontana the unity of opposites
(vi) The concepts of “okutomeggana” (to react chemically), ekitomeggano (chemical reaction) and ebitomeggero (reactors) are derivations from the borrowed (loan word) “atomu” or “akatoffaalikazimbakintu” (atom). What takes place at atomic level among atoms to cause a chemical change is what is called “okutomeggana” (to react chemically).
(vii) The concept of “enkyukakyuka ez’ebuziba” (chemical change) is a compound word from the Luganda word “ebuziba”or”obuziba” (the innermost part, the farthest part, the core). When compounded with the word “enkyukakyuka” (change) we get a new concept in chemistry: “enkyukakyuka ez’ebuziba (chemical change”). The opposite is “enkyukakyuka ezo kungulu” (physical change).
(viii) The concept of “omugendo” (movement in a straight line, a ray of light ) is derived from the Luganda verb “okugenda ” (to move, to go to stream out). Other technical terms created from this concept are:
• Omugendo gw’ekitangaala (light ray)
• Omugendo gw’amasannyalaze (current)
• Omugendo gw’amasoboza (movement of energy)
• Ekigendo (=ekibalo ky’omugendo) (vector )
The synonym of “omugendo” (movement) is “okuva” (Motion). Okuva refers to any kind of motion, whether it is a continuous motion in a straight line or not, even mere vibration of atoms in the chair I am seated on is okuva but not omugendo.
(ix) The concept of “omukwanaganyo (relation), or emikwanaganyo egy’Kibalangulo” (mathematical relations) are derivations from the Luganda word “okukwanaganya” (to relate or coordinate things) which is itself from the word “okukwana” (to make friendship). 
(x) The concept of “omukwataganyo” (function) and “omukwataganyo gw’ekibalangulo” (mathematical function) are derivations from the Luganda word “okukwataganya (to link, to connect, to make compatible). In mathematics “emikwataganyo” (functions) are a subset of “emikwanaganyo” (relations). 
(xi) The concepts of “omugereko” (set) and “emigereko gy’ekibalangulo” (mathematical sets) are derivations from the Luganda word “okugereka” (to arrange or to group a collection of things).
(xii) The mathematical concept “ebiyingo” (polynomials) or “Naamayingo” (polynomials) is a derivation from the Luganda word “ennyingo” (joint, term). Other concepts derived from the word “ennyingo” include:
• Nnyingemu (monomial)
• Nnyingobbiri (binomial)
• Nnyingosatu (trinomial)
• Nnyingo ezikwatagana (like terms)
• Nnyingo ezitakwatagana (unlike terms)
The above derivations are blends or compound words.
(xiii) The mathematical concept of “omuganyulo” or “omuganyulwo” (interest) is a derivation from the verb “okuganyula” (to benefit, to be useful to). Other terms derived from this concept include:
• Omuganyulo omwangu (simple interest)
• Omuganyulo omuzibuwavu (compound interest)
• Okubaza omuganyulo (calculating interest)
• Omuganyulo gwa banka (bank interest)
• Omuganyulo gw’ekyewolo (loan interest )
(xiv) The mathematical concept “omukendeezo” (discount) is derived from the word “okukendeeza” (to reduce). It can also be referred to as “ekikendeezo” (ekitundu ekikendeezeddwa ku mutemwa).
(xv) The mathematical concept “omujjuulirizo” or “enzijuulirizo” (top up, subsidy) is a derivation from “okujjuuliriza” (to top up).
(xvi) The concepts of “omugereeso” (math theory), “eggereeso” (theorem), and ekigereeso (scientific theory) are derivations from the word “okugereesa” (to theorise, to make a guess). From this we derive the concepts of:
• Omugereeso gwa namba (number theory)
• Eggereeso lya payisoggolaasi (the Pythagoras Theorem)
• Ekigereeso ky’essikirizo (the theory of gravity)
• Ekigereeso ky’Ensikirizo (the theory of attraction)
(xvii) The concept of “ekiyumba ekigerere” (green house) is a compound of two words “ekiyumba” (structure) and “ekigerere” (with measured conditions). The concept of “ekigerere” is itself derived from the verb “okugera” (to rationalize the conditions/the measurements). 
(xviii) The concept of “engerekera” (instincts) is derived from the noun “okugereka (to pre-determine, to pre-arrange). From the concept of engerekera (instinct), we can derive various concepts like:
• Engerekera y’okuva mu mbeera (the instinct of motion)
• Engerekera y’okwelwanako (the instinct of self defense)
• Namugereka” (the Author of instincts (God)
• Ebikolwa ebigerekere ( instinctive acts)
• Enneeyisa engerekere ( instinctive behavior)
(xix) From the mathematical concept of “Omufunza” (exponent) are derived the following mathematical concepts:
a) Ekifubza (exponentiation)
b) Omufunza (exponent)
c) Akafunza (the power of number )
d) Entobo, ekikolo, enfunzo (the base )
e) Okufundiza namba (to power a number)
In the exponent nm (Mu mufunza nm), “n” is the “entobo” or ekikolo” also called “enfunzo” (base) and m is akafunza (the power). The entire concept or topic is known as “mufunza”(exponentiation) whose meaning is a result of semantic extension of the ordinary meaning of the word “mufunza”(short form, tightening). If you are given 2 x 2x 2 x2 x 2 x 2 x 2 x 2. This can be indicated in short form as 28. In Luganda this may be called “okufunza”.

Luganda scientific concepts formed by combining methods:
IALI NGO has been authorised by terminologist Charles Muwanga to post this article from his Luganda scientific works on Luganda Wikipedia for free public consumption.
Mathematics and scientific concepts in any language are blends or compounds of bits or fragments (ebipapajjo) called morphons, affixes, and roots. Science concepts can be internalized by fragmentation (okupapajjula) to show the bits, fragments or small words that ere blended in their formation.
Combining bits of words to form science concepts is the formation of concepts by joining two (or more) words or morphenes into one new word. Some of the combined words are blends and others are compounds. Examples of concepts formed by blending are: 
a) “Omugerageranyo (mathematical ratio) is a blended concept formed by joining parts of two Luganda words “omuwendo”(a value) + okugerageranya (to compare).
b) Omulengera (the human mind) is a blended concept formed by joining parts of the words in the phrase “omwoyo ogukulengeza obigenda mu maaso mu bwongo”, meaning “the soul that shows you the outcomes of the processes going n in the brain”.
c) “Ekifunza”, a blend word from the Luganda phrase “ekibalo ekifunza emirundi” is now also used to refer to the mathematical concept for “exponentiation” as in the expression bn, involving two numbers, the entobo, ekikolo, or enfunzo (the base) “b” and akafunza (exponent/power) “n” e.g. 23. “Omufunza”, an exponent like 23, is also blend word from “omulundi omufunze” meaning “condensed multiplication” or “multiplication written in short form”. Generally, the two main methods of Luganda science and mathematics concepts formation by combining words or parts of words include:
a) Combining bits or fragments of words by Okugattika (Blending) 
b) Combining by Okugatta (Compounding)

Luganda scientific concepts formed by Blending (Okugattika ebigambo):
Okugattika ebigambo
Okugattika (blending) may be referred to as complex cutting, which is removing multiple parts from multiple words and joining the remaining parts into a single concept. Okugattaganya or okugattika is Luganda for blending, a concepts formation process in which “parts” of two or more words (but not the words on their eternity) combine to create a new word whose meaning is often a combination of the original words. Word formation by okugattika therefore results into change of spelling.
Do you know that most technical terms in science and mathematics are formed by blending (okugattaganya) and compounding (okugattika)? Yes, this is true but still many others are adopted and adapted using other techniques. Concepts formed by blending (okugattaganya), compounding (okugattika), eponyms (ebinnalinnya), and derivation (obuwango) are usually from the internal sources of a vernacular.
A good example of a blended English concept is the English word “motel” from the words “motor hotel”. The letters “-or” were clipped from the first word “motor” and the letters “ho-“ were clipped from the second word “hotel” living mot- and “-el from both words. When the Skeletons of the two are joined we get the new concept: “motel”. This is concept formation by blending.
Let me show you how we came to the Luganda concept for “energy”, “amasoboza”, by blending. Follow the following procedure:
(a) Get the foreign language concept “energy” and give it its simple English definition.
(b) Write out the simple English definition in vernacular, Luganda for this matter. The definition should be in form of a short sentence or phrase. Then look for the parts to cut out or clip to get the desired shortened concept. It is finished. In simple English, energy is “the ability to do work” 
(c) This is translated as “obusobozi okukola omulimu” which can further be paraphrased as “amaanyi agasobozesa okukola” (the power that is enables work to be done). Parts are cut out from “amaanyi agasobozesa okukola” to remain with the short Luganda concept “amasoboza” (Luganda for energy).
(d) Try to define the new concept formed using the phrase from which you formed it. Amasoboza is defined as “amaanyi agasobozesa okukola” (ability to work). Finished!
Blends in the Social Sciences
Words or phrase Blend Word
Embeera etabaganya abantu Entabagannyabantu (Human Society)
Entaba y’abantu oba ebintu ebirina obuvo obw’awamu Entababuvo (Community)
Essomo ly’entabaganya Essomantabaganyi (sociology)

Ekisobozesa ebikole okutondekebwawo Ekitondekabikole (Production)
Emitendera gy’enkwanaganya y’ebikolebwa Emikwanaganyo (Relations)

Because the spellings changes, these mathematical shapes arealso said to be formed by blending not compounding.

ey’Amatenkane (Rhomboid)
Nakimu ng’amaweto abiri genkanankana Nakimu ey’amalongo 
Nakimu ey’amalongo= (isosceles trapezoid)
Feesinnyingi or bwenyibungi (polyhedron) refers to any three-dimensional figure (enkula ey’empimo essatu) with flat surfaces which are polygons. 
The Greek root -hedron means a face (Luganda: feesi, obwenyi) asin Tetrahedron (feesimwenda/bwenyimwenda), a solid figure with nine faces. These shapes are vernacularised by compounding not blending because the compounded words are joined directly without changing the spellings. There are three common bwenyibungi (polyhedral):
These are also Bwenyibungi (Polyhedrons):
 Feesimukaaga/Bwenyimukaaga (Tyetrahedron)
 Ekigulumiro ekya mawetasatu (Triangular prism)
 Kyesatuza (Cube)
 Ekigulumiro ekya bwenyimusanvu (Pentagonal prism)
 Ekigulumiro ekya bwenyimunaana (hexagonal prism)
 Ekigulumiro ekya bwenyikumi (Octagonal prism)
 Ekigulumiro ekya bwenyikuminemu (Decagonal prism)
 Ekigulumiro ekya bweenyikkuminannya (Dedecagonal prism)
 Feesi-abirimumukaaga (Great rhombicuboctahedron)
 Feesinkaagamubbiri (Great rhombicosidodecahedron)
 Feesikikuminabbiri (Dodecahedron)
 Feesimunaana (bwenyimunaana) (Octahedron)
• Formed by blending or acronyms
Words from which Parts are to be cut out Resulting Blended Word
Omubalanguzi ky’agereesa Omugereeso (Mathematical Theory)
Omusingi gw’ennamba Omusimba (Number base)
Ennamba ekuuma ekifo Enkuuma-kifo (placeholder)
Ennukuta ekuuma ekifo ky’ennamba” Enkuumakifo (Variable)
Eriwo awatali namba magnify Entamanyika (variable)
Kitundu kya mukutule ekya waggulu Kinnawaggulu (Nominator)
Kitundu kyamukutule ekya wansi Kinnawansi (Denominator
Nambuluzo Eyawamu Esingayo NESI (GCF)
Enkubise Eyawamu Esembayo ESE (LCM) 
(k) Other Luganda concepts formed by blending in Mathematics
• Matrix, Fractions, Decimal numbers, variation
Words from which Parts are to be cut out Resulting Blend Word
Engeri ey’okusengeka Ensengeka (Order/arrangement)
Omugereko gw’ebisengeke Omusengeko (pattern)
Ensengeka eyemalirira Ensekekera (System)
Ekibalo ky’emisengeko Ekisengeko (Matrix)
Ekibalo kya mugobansonga Ekigobansonga (Variation Maths)
Omuwendo omukutulemu Omukutule (Fraction)
Omuwendo ogw’akatonnyeze Omutonnyeze (Decimal number)
Ennamba ezekubisibwamu Enkubisa (Coefficients)
Ennamba eva mu kukubisa enkubisa Enkubise (Multiple)
Ennamba ezirambulula namba endala Ennambuluzo (Factors)
Omuwendo ogutondekebwawo nga wekubisizzaamu ennamba(enkubisa) Omutondeko (Product)
• Sets, Ratios, Rates, Relations, and Functions
Words or phrase Blend word
Omuwendo omugerageranye n’omulala Omugerageranyo (Ratio)
Ekibalo eky’ebigerageranye ku buli namunigina Ekigerageranyo (Rate)
Emiwendo emikwanaganye Emikwanaganyo (Mathematical relations)
Emikwanaganyo emikwataganye Emikwataganyo (Mathematical function)
Emiwendo emigereke Emigereko (Mathematical sets)
Omukwanaganyo omusengeke Omusengeko (Statistical pattern)
Obuwanvu bw’olugendo Obuwanvo (Distance)
Obuzibu ekiwanvu Obuzibuwavu (complixity)
• Equations, Inequalities, Probability, Coordinates, Symmetry 
Words or phrase Blend word
Olukoloboze olwenkanya enjuyi Olwenkanyanjuyi (Symmetry)
Namba ezekubira Nakyekubira (Inequality)
Omuwendo omukwanaganye n’omulala Omukwanaganyo (Mathematical relation)
Ekikube ekikwanaganya omugereko gw’emiwendo ogumu n’omulala Ekikwanaganya (Mapping diagram)
Omuwendo ogukwatagana n’omulala gumu gwokka Omukwataganyo (Mathematical function)
Ekikube ekikwataganya emikwataganyo Ekikwataganya (Coordinate graph)
Ekibalo ky’Omukisa Ekibazamukisa (Probability)
• Locus, Location, Direction, Position, Focus
Words or phrase Blend word
Obutonnyeze, akatonnyeze oba ekifo ekintu we kiri ( we kinoonyerwa) Obunoonyero (Location)
Obutonnyeze bwonna ekintu mwe kiyita Obuyitiro=Obuufu (Mathematical Locus)
Obutonnyeze, akatonnyeze, oba ekifo awasinziirwa Obusinziiro (Mathematical focus)
Oludda Obutonnyeze gye bwolekedde Obwolekero (Direction)
Obutonnyeze, akatonnyeze oba ekifo ekintu we kisangibwa Obusangiro (Position)
• Polynomials
Words or phrase Blendword
Ekibalo ky’ennyingo Ekiyingo (Polynomial)
Namba ez’ennyingo ez’enjawulo Naamayingo (Polynomial)
Manya: (a) Ennyingo is Luganda for a mathematical “term”
(b) Mathematical Dialectics (Mugobansonga) explores relationships between situations

Ebintu ebipangiddwa mu kubaza okw’ekikugu Ebipango (installations)

Ebyobunyukufu: The Necessary concepts for Literary analysis in Luganda
Do you know that Knowledge of literary analysis is essential to understand scientific and mathematical literature? This is the reason I have tried to build the key concepts of literary analysis here below:
(a) Luganda concepts for Literature and literacy
Ebinukuto/Ebinyukuto (Literature) Ebigambo n’ebigambululo eby’ennukuta
Obunukuufu/obunyukufu (Literacy) Obusobozi bw’okusoma n’okuwandiika
Ebikunu (Genre) Ebika by’ebinunukuto
(b) Luganda terminology associated with literature
Words or phrase Blend word
Ekiwandiiko ekirimu okulombojja Ekirombojjo (Novel)
Ekifaananyi ky’embeera ennyuvu Ekifaanyuvu (imagery)
Olugero oluwa ebyafaayo mu ngeri ey’okugereesa (okuteebereza) Olugereeso (myth)
Okunnyonnyola gyenvudde wo Gyenvuddewo (Autobiography)
Okunnyonnyola gye nvudde ku muntu omulala Gyenvuddewe (Biography)
Olugereeso nga bakazannyirizi baalwo bisolo Olugereebi (fable)
Olugero olulinga olw’ekirooto Olugerooto (fantasy)
Okwatula ennukuta ezikola ekigambo Okunukukya (to spell a word)
Embeera etiisa Entiisa (tragedy)
Omuzira ow’entiisa Omutiisa (tragic hero)
Olugero oluzze lulandizibwa okuva edda Olulandizo (folktale)
Olugero oluzze lunaawuzibwa okuva emabega Olunaawuzo (legend)
Ekigambo oba ekigambululo ekyawukana n’amakulu gakyo ago kungulu Ekigewukano (irony)
Manya:
(c) More Forms of Literature in Luganda
Words or phrase Blend word
Olulimi ng’amakulu g’ekigambo gawukana n’ekigambo ekikozeseddwa Olugewukano (irony)
Ekigambululo ng’amakulu gaakyo gawukana n’ekigambululo kyonnyini Ekigewukano ironic statement)

Concepts associated with Engineering and Production 
Words or phrase Blend word
Okukola kwa Katonda Okutonda (the Productive activity of God )
Okutonda ebikolera Okutondeka (to produce, production by man,to manufacture)

Omuntu atondeka ebirungi Omutondekabirungi (Fine artist )
Omuntu atondeka ebinyuma Omutondekabinyuma (Performing artist)
Entondeka erimu ekikolwa ekirimu okunonooza amateeka ga sayansi n’ekibalo Ekinonoozo (Engineering)
Omukungu mu kulondooza Omunonooza (Engineer)
Ekipango ekirimu ekinonoozo ekizibuwavu Ekinonoggo (Engine)

Ekikolwa eky’okutondeyiriza Ekitondeyirizo(to manufacture)
Note:
• Okutondeka (Okutonda ebikoleka=production or to produce)
• Ekinonoozo ky’obusannyalazo (Electrical Engineering)
• Ekinonoozo ky’okuzimba (Civil engineering)
• Ekitonguyirizo (Manufacturing)
• Ekinonoozo eky’ekitambu zo (Mechanical Engineering)
a) Essomabuzimbe (Chemistry)
Words or phrase Blend word
Obubage obw’ekizimbe Obuzimbe (Structure)
Essomo ly’obuzimbe bw’enzitoyo Essomabuzimbe (Chemistry)
Embeera ereetera ekintu okuzitowa Enzitoya (Mass)
Ekimmemmette Ekimette (Matter)
Obuntu obutono ennyo Obutonniinya 
Obuntu obutini ennyo Obutinniinya (Elementary particles)
Obutiniinya obusibukako amasannyalaze Obusannyalazo(Electrons)
Obutonniinya obukontana n’obusanyalazo Obukontanyo (Protons)
Akantu akatono Akatono (tiny thing)
